title.no-sidewalk: Should there be a No Sidewalk label here?

curb-ramp.title: Correct Curb Ramp
curb-ramp.example-1-2-3-4: This label is correctly placed at the bottom of a curb ramp

no-curb-ramp.title: Correct Missing Curb Ramp
no-curb-ramp.example-1-2-3: This intersection is lacking a curb ramp
no-curb-ramp.example-4: This crosswalk indicates there should be a curb ramp here

obstacle.title: Correct Obstacle
obstacle.example-1: These construction cones are blocking a pedestrian crosswalk
obstacle.example-2: This tree blocks the entire sidewalk
obstacle.example-3: This pole blocks the sidewalk and a curb ramp entrance
obstacle.example-4: This fire hydrant blocks the sidewalk

surface-problem.title: Correct Surface Problem
surface-problem.example-2: Brick sidewalks are bumpy and can be difficult to pass
surface-problem.example-4: There is a lot of grass growing between the sidewalk cracks

no-sidewalk.title: Correct No Sidewalk
no-sidewalk.example-1-2: This is an abruptly ending sidewalk

crosswalk.title: Correct Crosswalk
crosswalk.example-1-2-3: This label is correctly placed on a painted crosswalk
crosswalk.example-4: This label is correctly placed on a crosswalk with fading paint

signal.title: Correct Pedestrian Signal
signal.example-1-2-3: This label is correctly placed at the base of a pole with a button for a pedestrian signal
signal.example-4: This pole has the light and button for a pedestrian signal

curb-ramp.title: Incorrect Curb Ramp
curb-ramp.example-1-2: Sidewalk to driveway transitions are not curb ramps

no-curb-ramp.title: Incorrect Missing Curb Ramp
no-curb-ramp.example-1: Residential walkways should not be labeled as a missing curb ramp
no-curb-ramp.example-2-4: This is not located on a pedestrian path
no-curb-ramp.example-3: This is not an intersection pedestrians should cross at

obstacle.title: Incorrect Obstacle
obstacle.example-1: There is enough space to comfortably maneuver around this pole
obstacle.example-2: This pole located between, but not on these curb ramps
obstacle.example-3: This tree is not on the pedestrian path
obstacle.example-4: There is enough space to comfortably maneuver around this lid

surface-problem.title: Incorrect Surface Problem
surface-problem.example-1: Surface problems on curb ramps should be marked with a curb ramp label with a higher severity
surface-problem.example-2: This gravel is not on the pedestrian path
surface-problem.example-3: This grass is not on the pedestrian path
surface-problem.example-4: Normal sidewalk tiles are not surface problems

no-sidewalk.title: Incorrect No Sidewalk
no-sidewalk.example-1: Narrow sidewalks should not be labeled as no sidewalk
no-sidewalk.example-2: Driveways should not be labeled as no sidewalk
no-sidewalk.example-3: Traffic medians should not be labeled as no sidewalk
no-sidewalk.example-4: Alleyways and side streets should not be labeled as no sidewalk

crosswalk.title: Incorrect Crosswalk
crosswalk.example-1: Crossings with no visual indicator should not be labeled as crosswalks
crosswalk.example-2: Stop lines for cars should not be labeled as crosswalks
crosswalk.example-3-4: Speed bumps should not be labeled as crosswalks

signal.title: Incorrect Pedestrian Signal
signal.example-1-2: This sign does not indicate when pedestrians can cross the street
signal.example-3: This traffic light is only for vehicles, not for pedestrians
signal.example-4: This pole does not have a pedestrian signal button

mission-start.title: Validate {{n}} {{label_type}} labels
mission-start.body: Your mission is to determine the correctness of __LABELCOUNT_PLACEHOLDER__ __LABELTYPE_PLACEHOLDER__ labels placed by other users!

mission-complete.title: Great Job!
mission-complete.body-1: You just validated {{n}} Curb Ramp labels.
mission-complete.body-2: You just validated {{n}} Missing Curb Ramp labels.
mission-complete.body-4: You just validated {{n}} Surface Problem labels.
mission-complete.body-7: You just validated {{n}} No Sidewalk labels.
mission-complete.body-10: You just validated {{n}} Pedestrian Signal labels.
mission-complete.no-new-mission-body: Click the button to start exploring

mobile.info-title-no-curb-ramp: What is a Missing Curb Ramp?

slide-1.title: {{labelType}}
slide-1.description: Curb ramps are often found on both ends of crosswalks, or when a sidewalk continue on the other side of the street, even without crosswalk.

slide-2.title: Driveway
slide-2.description: Driveways are not curb ramps. They are designed for vehicles and not pedestrians. Driveways should not be labeled as Curb Ramps.

slide-3.title: Garage
slide-3.description: Driveways to garages are not curb ramps. Driveways should not be labeled as Curb Ramps.

slide-1.title: {{labelType}}
slide-1.description: Sidewalk intersections should have curb ramps—ideally two per corner. If a corner has a sidewalk but does not have a curb ramp, place the Missing Curb Ramp label where you think a curb ramp should exist.

slide-2.title: Residential walkways
slide-2.description: Residential walkways should not be labeled as Missing Curb Ramps.

slide-3.title: Not on pedestrian path
slide-3.description: Curb ramps are not needed at paths not intended for pedestrians to pass.

slide-4.title: Missing sidewalk
slide-4.description: For corners with no sidewalks, use the No Sidewalk label rather than a Missing Curb Ramp label.

slide-1.title: {{labelType}}
slide-1.description:
Obstacles are barriers that impede pedestrian pathways for people using wheelchairs, walkers, or other mobility aids.

Not all fire hydrants, poles, and signs are obstacles—only those that clearly obstruct pedestrian paths.

slide-2.title: Ample space to maneuver around
slide-2.description: The motorcycle is parked on the side; there is ample space for pedestrians on the remaining space of the sidewalk.

slide-3.title: Obstacle not on sidewalk
slide-3.description:
This traffic cone is not on a pedestrian pathway so it should not be marked as an Obstacle.

Only mark obstacles on sidewalks, crosswalks, and other pedestrian pathways.

slide-4.title: Moving object
slide-4.description: The car seems to be moving in the image and should not be labeled as an Obstacle.

slide-1.title: {{labelType}}
slide-1.description: If something on the sidewalk or crosswalk surface would make it uncomfortable or impossible to cross, it should be labeled as a Surface Problem.

slide-2.title: Normal sidewalk tiles
slide-2.description: Normal sidewalk tiles (without gaps, cracks or bumps) are not surface problems.

slide-3.title: Not on pedestrian path
slide-3.description:
This gravel is not on a pedestrian pathway so it should not be marked as a Surface Problem.

Only mark surface problems on sidewalks, crosswalks, and other pedestrian pathways.

slide-1.title: {{labelType}}
slide-1.description: If a street side does not have a sidewalk, please mark it with a No Sidewalk label.

slide-2.title: Median
slide-2.description: A median that separates two directions of a traffic and is not intended for pedestrians should not be labeled as No Sidewalk.

slide-3.title: Pavement
slide-3.description: There is a sidewalk here. It should not be marked as No Sidewalk.

slide-1.title: {{labelType}}
slide-1.description:
A crosswalk is a legally defined space to cross a road.

Crosswalks are often indicated by parallel dashed lines.

slide-2.title: No visual indicator
slide-2.description: Crossings with no visual indicator should not be labeled as Crosswalks.

slide-3.title: Stop line
slide-3.description: Stop lines for cars should not be labeled as Crosswalks.

slide-4.title: Speed bump
slide-4.description: Speed bumps should not be labeled as Crosswalks.

slide-1.title: {{labelType}}
slide-1.description:
A pedestrian signal indicates when pedestrians can cross the street and provides time for them to do so safely.

Some pedestrian signals are activated by a pedestrian push button at waist height.

slide-2.title: Signage
slide-2.description: This sign does not indicate when pedestrians can cross the street.

slide-3.title: Pole
slide-3.description: This pole does not show traffic signals to pedestrians.

slide-4.title: Traffic light for vehicles
slide-4.description: This traffic light is only for vehicles, not for pedestrians.
